comments.text:
GRESHAM’S LAW is a principle of economics that states that when debased 
currency (like a counterfeit or inflated currency) is in circulation along 
with currencies retaining their full values, those of full value will 
disappear over time. Simply stated, the phrase “Bad money drives out the 
good” is an expression of Gresham’s Law.

Gresham’s Law has found applications outside economics. For example, 
successful propaganda and disinformation campaigns have as their objective 
the driving out of good thought by substituting a circulation of 
counterfeit thought. If successful, these efforts result in the public 
discussing the false ideas and largely ignoring the valid ones.  ... enough 
said ...

I believe he is using MRI to do the brain scan, as there are other scan

you that brains are not fully analyzed and understood by neuro scientists 
and engineers yet, and from my undergrad level of neuro engineering 
knowledge, I still keep my skepticism on his conclusion of towards the 
study.  confirmation bias has always existed in social science and many 
earlier research papers are discredited as a result of that.

I am sure there are many insights you can get from ones' study, but it's 
difficult yet important to hold your critical thinking skills when reading 
ones' studies because it's really easy for an author to uncontinuously mix 
his views into the documents he wrote (even if its peer reviewed)
comments.author: Hang Wu (VoiceOfTheVoiceless)

comments.text:
+Hang Wu
 Yes, I do understand your skepticism and I am not asking you to take my 
words for facts. It's good to questions things, it shows signs of 
intelligence. This isn't my study and I am not spewing any type of “PR 
campaign.” But my original question was meant for Yaboirado, but since you 
must know, this is an actually study performed by Dr. Joe R. Feagin, who is 
a world known sociologist and social theorist. Dr. Feagin is a Harvard 
University graduated, a Pulitzer Prize winner and was president of the 
American Sociology Association from 1999-2000. Dr. Feagin field of study is 
on extensive research on racial and gender issues, especially in regards to 
the United States.

The brain scan imaging study I’ve mentioned is in full detail in his book 
‘Systemic Racism: A Theory of Oppression’ published in 2006. The book gives 
a historical and contemporary view on white-on-black oppression, and not 
just African-Americans, but people of color in general in American society. 
Dr. Feagin has been doing this study for years and his facts are in full 
detail in his book and research page that you can get online. But hey if 
you doubt my sincerity, there are some YouTube video that shows Dr. Feagin 
discussing his research and several of his other books that deals on race 
issues. You can also find the brain scan race study publish in the Journal 
Psychological Science and online.

we all perceived to be Mexican or Latin American; it turns out he was 
Eastern European.

comments.text:
+SAcHa Like I said, here in the U.S. race is more about perception than 
anything else. Which is why even if your ethnic origins are from Eurasia, 
the Middle East, North Africa, or even Northern India/Pakistan, if you LOOK 
"White" (as in European or of European descent), generally have fair 
skin, and can speak perfect English in a clear North American accent, 
people are willing to accept you as White. The word "Caucasian" here in the 
U.S. is merely a synonym for White, as Central Asians/Eurasians and 
Middle-Eastern folks who are light-skinned and European looking, are also 
considered to be White. Even some Latinos who are light-skinned and are of 
mainly Spanish origin (whose ancestors have not mixed with the Native 
population in the Americas) can pass as White people here in the U.S. Only 
those who have obvious darker skin tones, darker hair/eye color, and look 
absolutely nothing like a European White person are considered to be 
something else. The ethnic minority groups here in the U.S. are mainly 
classified as follows: Black (negroes of African/Caribbean origin), 
Hispanic/Latino (all Latin American folks hat are visibly non-White), Asian 
most of whom are Oriental (Chinese, Japanese, Korean) or Southeast Asian 
(Filipino, Indonesian, Malaysian, Vietnamese, Laoasian, Cambodian, etc.), 
but there are also quite a few Indians & other "Desi" people, and of course 
the Middle-Eastern and Eurasians who visibly don't look White. Fiy, there 
is also the etnic category of the Native Americans as well as other natives 
like the Inuit (Eskimos), etc. And that is basically how race 
is categorized here in the U.S.

So, when Sydney English referred to herself as "Caucasian," what she meant 
to say is that she is a general White person of European origin (most 
likely Anglo-Saxon), as her name would indicate.

conservatives.

comments.text:
+Xombie007 did this come from Jon Stewart's The Daily Show, or The Colbert 
Report? 

I do look into statistics.
 
Incarceration Trends in America
•From 1980 to 2008, the number of people incarcerated in America 
quadrupled-from roughly 500,000 to 2.3 million people
•Today, the US is 5% of the World population and has 25% of world prisoners.
•Combining the number of people in prison and jail with those under parole 
or probation supervision, 1 in ever y 31 adults, or 3.2 percent of the 
population is under some form of correctional control
Racial Disparities in Incarceration
•African Americans now constitute nearly 1 million of the total 2.3 million 
incarcerated population
•African Americans are incarcerated at nearly six times the rate of whites
•Together, African American and Hispanics comprised 58% of all prisoners in 
2008, even though African Americans and Hispanics make up approximately one 
quarter of the US population
•According to Unlocking America, if African American and Hispanics were 
incarcerated at the same rates of whites, today's prison and jail 
populations would decline by approximately 50%
•One in six black men had been incarcerated as of 2001. If current trends 
continue, one in three black males born today can expect to spend time in 
prison during his lifetime
•1 in 100 African American women are in prison
•Nationwide, African-Americans represent 26% of juvenile arrests, 44% of 
youth who are detained, 46% of the youth who are judicially waived to 
criminal court, and 58% of the youth admitted to state prisons (Center on 
Juvenile and Criminal Justice).
Drug Sentencing Disparities
•About 14 million Whites and 2.6 million African Americans report using an 
illicit drug
•5 times as many Whites are using drugs as African Americans, yet African 
Americans are sent to prison for drug offenses at 10 times the rate of 
Whites
•African Americans represent 12% of the total population of drug users, but 
38% of those arrested for drug offenses, and 59% of those in state prison 
for a drug offense.
•African Americans serve virtually as much time in prison for a drug 
offense (58.7 months) as whites do for a violent offense (61.7 months). 
(Sentencing Project)
Contributing Factors
• Inner city crime prompted by social and economic isolation
• Crime/drug arrest rates: African Americans represent 12% of monthly drug 
users, but comprise 32% of persons arrested for drug possession
• "Get tough on crime" and "war on drugs" policies
• Mandatory minimum sentencing, especially disparities in sentencing for 
crack and powder cocaine possession
• In 2002, blacks constituted more than 80% of the people sentenced under 
the federal crack cocaine laws and served substantially more time in prison 
for drug offenses than did whites, despite that fact that more than 2/3 of 
crack cocaine users in the U.S. are white or Hispanic
• "Three Strikes"/habitual offender policies
• Zero Tolerance policies as a result of perceived problems of school 
violence; adverse affect on black children.
• 35% of black children grades 7-12 have been suspended or expelled at some 
point in their school careers compared to 20% of Hispanics and 15% of whites
Effects of Incarceration
• Jail reduces work time of young people over the next decade by 25-30 
percent when compared with arrested youths who were not incarcerated
• Jails and prisons are recognized as settings where society's infectious 
diseases are highly concentrated
• Prison has not been proven as a rehabilitation for behavior, as 
two-thirds of prisoners will reoffend
Exorbitant Cost of Incarceration: Is it Worth It?
• About $70 billion dollars are spent on corrections yearly
• Prisons and jails consume a growing portion of the nearly $200 billion we 
spend annually on public safety

comments.author: Ian Mercer

comments.text:
+Lanoira13
Lol, I know hun, that was the joke.

You do say it correctly, it should be "I couldn't care less".
If one says they *could* care less, they are implying the *do* care; The 
opposite of their intended meaning.
"Another thin*g* coming" is actually supposed to be "Another thin*k* 
coming". It's basically said when someone has done something untoward or 
otherwise not awesome. The implication is "You thought that was a good 
thing to say/do? You have another think coming!"  (Basically telling them 
to rethink their actions/words)

Also, you are correct about Due. =) "With all *due* respect", stating "With 
all the respect that is owed.".
"With all do respect", while being essentially a non-sense statement, would 
be the equivalent of telling some one to do something with respect. (Just 
in poor English)

I get what you were saying, I was just enjoying the way people butcher 
common idioms and colloquialisms. You were saying them correctly though, so 
none of the jest making was directed at you =)
comments.author: Tenshi Chan

comments.text:
+Tenshi Chan
I get what you're saying. (I always say "couldn't care less") But the phase 
is supposed to be due. Due is an adjective, do is a verb....

Nope, the country is Netherlands, it used to be part of the Holy Roman 
Empire or the German Empire as Gelre + Flanders (aka as the Lower 
Counties). Holland is part of the Netherlands, Holland is located to the 
north east, and it basically consists of two provinces. Think of it this

(Colorado, and a bunch of other states - that's Holland).

comments.text:
Yes, and I was commenting on the ridiculousness of stereotyping an 
extremely diverse and often controversial country. Making comments 
generalizing all "Americans" as the "biggest rednecks in history" is just 
pathetic. There are all kinds of "Americans" who do not share the opinions 
of those that left racist remarks, and yet we are pooled into the 
stereotype that "Americans are rednecks". The intention behind my comment 
was not about defending the wrong and hurtful comments about the Miss 
America Winner, but instead about the comment generalizing all "Americans" 
as stupid and moronic. One of the reasons why others tend to feel so angry 
about "Americans" is that the whole range of emotions (from joy to pain) 
concerning social issues, such as racism, exists here in American society. 
The greatest joys of human achievement and the worst atrocities against 
human dignity have occurred in this diverse country. So, when ignorant 
people make hateful comments about other hateful comments, and thus 
reducing ALL "Americans" as rednecks, I feel compelled to point out the 
injustice. Thank you for sharing your comment. I appreciate the dialog.

comments.text:
Yeah, there's a word for it; it's call xenophobia. Xenophobia is an 
irrational or deep-rooted fear of foreigners or fear or hatred of the 
unfamiliar. Xenophobia can manifest itself in people in so many ways 
involving the relations and views of an ingroup towards an outgroup, 
including a fear of losing identity, suspicion of its activities, 
aggression, and desire to eliminate its presence to secure a presumed 
purity. This one of the reason as to why there is such racism in the U.S.

Basically it's people in a country, nation, or community that fear any 
ethnic or nationality of taking over their country, nation, or community, 
and the ingroup losing their identity or culture.

Now, in the case of America, you have to tell yourself what exactly is an 
American culture or identity; considering every culture and nationality 
makes up the American culture. I live in NYC, and I see this "melting pot" 
culture everyday. The sweet and sour chicken is Chinese, the fries I 
eat are from Belgium,  hamburgers are from Germany, the restaurant where I 
eat sole food is African-American, the crispy Taco I like so much is 
Mexican, and the pizza with pepperoni I always order is Italian. So, I 
don't understand with a country such as the U.S., where does this 
xenophobia comes from?!

comments.text:
+Eagle027 Excuse me?
First of all "holocaust" is not a synonym of "genocide," so don't get it 
confused.
Secondly, the fact that the genocide began around 98 years ago (1915 is 
year most historians agree upon) doesn't change the fact that "The Young 
Turks" is the name of the group that committed it. I feel it's a very poor 
choice of name.
Third, what my government did (while absolutely atrocious) has NOTHING to 
do with this. Am I walking around calling myself "Peter Burnett" or 
"General Kibbe" or "Governor Weller" or "Lewis Cass" or "George Gaines"?? 
No. I'm not. I am not associating myself with perpetrators of genocide to 
"sell" a brand, which is EXACTLY what TYT is doing. They're running a page 
under that name to bring people in to watch their content. And I find it 
extremely inappropriate.
